description: Use the passive to focus on the action or result rather than the doer.
pattern: be + past participle (am/is/are/was/were/been/being) or get + past participle
examples: Present simple: The report is written every week.
Past simple: The window was broken yesterday.
Present perfect: The tickets have been sold.
Future: The work will be finished tomorrow.
Get-passive: He got promoted last year.
tips: Use 'by + agent' only when the doer is important: The cake was made by Anna.
Avoid get-passive in very formal writing; use 'be' instead.
mistakes: Forgetting 'be' (The book read by me → The book was read by me).
Using active order with passive verbs (The report was written John → by John).
note: Continuous passive: be + being + V3 (The work is being done now).

description: In formal reports, use passive reporting verbs to avoid naming the source.
pattern: It is/was said/reported/claimed that + clause OR Subject + is/was said to + base/infinitive
examples: It is said that the team will win.
It was reported that prices had risen.
She is believed to be abroad.
They were thought to have left early.
tips: Use 'to be' + base for present/future ideas; use 'to have + V3' for past ideas.
Common reporting verbs: say, believe, think, report, consider, expect.
mistakes: Mixing tenses (is reported prices rose → is reported that prices have risen).
Leaving out 'to' in the infinitive (is believed be → is believed to be).
note: Passive reporting keeps the focus on information, not on who said it.

description: Use modals to express degrees of certainty about now or the past.
pattern: Present: must / might / may / could / can’t + base; Past: must / might / may / could / can’t + have + V3
examples: She must be at work now.
He might be tired.
They can’t be ready yet.
She must have forgotten her keys.
They may have missed the bus.
He can’t have finished so quickly.
tips: 'Must' = strong belief yes; 'can’t' = strong belief no; 'might/may/could' = maybe.
Use 'have + V3' to talk about past guesses.
mistakes: Using present form for past (He must forget → He must have forgotten).
Using 'couldn’t' instead of 'can’t' in present speculation (He couldn’t be here now → He can’t be here now).
note: Don’t use 'must not' for negative speculation; use 'can’t'.

description: Show that someone arranges for another person to do the action.
pattern: have/get + object + past participle; make/let/allow + object + base form
examples: I had my hair cut yesterday.
We got the car repaired.
They made me wait outside.
She let him borrow the car.
The school allows students to use laptops.
tips: Use 'have/get + object + V3' to talk about services.
Use 'make + object + base' (no 'to'); 'let + object + base'; 'allow + object + to + base'.
mistakes: Adding 'to' after make/let (make me to wait → make me wait; let me to go → let me go).
Using active V1 instead of V3 in have/get (had my car fix → had my car fixed).

description: Use -ing or -ed clauses to show time, reason, result, or condition in a compact form.
pattern: -ing clause (active meaning) / -ed clause (passive meaning) + main clause
examples: Feeling tired, she went home early.
Finished with his work, he took a break.
Built in 1920, the bridge is still strong.
Not knowing the answer, I stayed quiet.
tips: Make sure the -ing subject matches the main clause subject (no dangling participles).
Use commas to show the clause is extra information.
mistakes: Dangling participles (Walking down the street, the trees were tall → Walking down the street, I saw tall trees).
Using -ing when passive is needed (Being stolen, the car… → Stolen, the car…).
note: 'Having + V3' shows earlier action: Having finished, she left.

description: Invert auxiliary and subject to add emphasis or a formal tone.
pattern: Negative adverbial + auxiliary + subject + verb (Never/Hardly/Not only/No sooner…) or Conditional inversion (Should/Were/Had)
examples: Never have I seen such a view.
Hardly had we started when it rained.
Not only is she smart, but she is also kind.
Should you need help, call me.
Were I you, I’d wait.
Had I known, I would have called.
tips: After hardly/scarcely/no sooner, use past perfect in the first clause and inversion.
Conditional inversion replaces 'if' in formal style.
mistakes: Forgetting inversion (Never I have seen → Never have I seen).
Using simple past instead of past perfect with hardly/no sooner (Hardly we started → Hardly had we started).
note: Add a comma after the first inverted clause when needed.

description: Split a sentence to emphasize a specific part using 'it' or 'what'.
pattern: It is/was + focus + that/who + clause OR What-clause + be + focus
examples: It was John who called you.
It is patience that you need.
What I need is a break.
What matters is honesty.
tips: Use 'who' for people after the focus, 'that' for things/other cases.
Clefts highlight new or important information in a sentence.
mistakes: Using 'what' with a full clause after it (What I need that is… → What I need is…).
Dropping 'that/who' in it-clefts (It was John called → It was John who called).
note: You can move the focus: It was yesterday that she arrived.

description: Use the base form after certain verbs/expressions to show necessity or importance.
examples: They insisted that he stay longer.
It is essential that she be on time.
The doctor recommended that I take a rest.
The manager demanded that the report be ready.
tips: Common triggers: suggest, recommend, insist, demand, essential, important, vital, necessary.
No -s for third person; use base form or 'be'.
mistakes: Adding -s (He suggested she goes → she go).
Using past when base form is needed (They insisted that he stayed → he stay).
note: In British English, 'should' + base is also common: They insisted that he should stay.
